title: Which is correct, 'He worked there for 5 years' or 'He worked there 5 years'? - Quora

response.answer_text: He worked there for five years. [Meaning that at some time in the past he worked at a given place for a period of five years. Although the time is undetermined it is implied by the past tense of the verb that the period in question is over. The grammatical tense is known as the past definite.] Equally correct but with a difference in implied meaning would be: He has worked there for five years; but here the implied meaning is that not only has he worked there for five years but he is still working there ie that his work period continues. The grammatical tense here is called th past historic tense. To say ““He worked there five years” is not incorrect but is a loose idiomatic version of the past definite passing over or eclipsing the preposition ‘for’ it being left unsaid but understood that he worked there for a duration of five years and would not be encouraged in the written form.

the ‘He’ you mean here, does he still work in there up to now or he quits it already? if he does work there still, the sentence must be he has worked there for 5 years, but if you refer him to work there in the past and now not anymore, better use these alternative he had worked there for 5 years/ he worked there for 5 years.
